title: Latin (1301) Biblia Sacra Vulgata Latina
description:
Latin (1301) Biblia Sacra Vulgata Latina

This manuscript represents Saint Jerome's significant translation of the Greek and Hebrew Scriptures into Latin, a monumental work in the history of Christianity. Recognized as authoritative during the Council of Trent in 1546, Jerome's translation played a pivotal role in shaping the theological and liturgical landscape of the Western Church. The text includes a Latin introduction and an expanded Apocrypha, which features Psalm 151, the Epistle to the Laodiceans, 3 & 4 Esdras, and the Prayer of Manasses.

This version of the Bible, known as the Vulgate, became the Catholic Church's official Latin Bible and remained so for centuries. Its translation was a rigorous endeavor to make the Scriptures more accessible to the Latin-speaking world, ensuring uniformity in liturgical readings and theological studies. The inclusion of expanded apocryphal books highlights the diverse traditions and texts considered significant in Christian history. This particular manuscript from 1301 is a testament to the enduring influence of Jerome's translation, showcasing the rich tradition of biblical scholarship and religious devotion in the medieval period.
